results.title: Plastics
results.creator_credit: Terry Sanders, Marilyn Sanders, Holt and King Screen Films
results.brief_description: Looks at plastics being moulded in the factory into a variety of products highlighting the versatility of this product and its importance in our daily lives. Non-narrated using creative and evocative music and sounds. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Plasticity in the Central Nervous System (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows three contemporary research approaches to neuronal plasticity in the adult. Approach one is the investigation of naturally regrowing neuronal tissue in the olfactory system. Approach two is nerve recovery after experimental lesioning, and approach three is the long term potentiation of neuronal stimulation

results.title: Plastic art
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: A sculptor creates a bronze statuary group on the theme: “Man’s confidence in his fellow-man”. We see the preliminary sketch, the wire skeleton on which the rough figures are built up as the sculptor observes living models, the measurements of the clay group being taken, and the casting of the life-size bronze replica.

results.title: Plasma: the fourth state of matter
results.creator_credit: Robert Mack and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: Explores the properties and potential uses of plasma, the fourth state of matter, in which energy causes the atoms themselves to break down into free electrons, protons or ions. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Plapp
results.brief_description: Plapp, a cormorant, was found in the Scilly Isles so thickly covered with oil that he could neither swim nor fly. After he was cleaned up he became so tame that he even went fishing with his rescuer and dog. Narrated by Johnny Morris.
results.description: Plapp, a cormorant, was found in the Scilly Isles so thickly covered with oil that he could neither swim nor fly. After he was cleaned up he became so tame that he even went fishing with his rescuer and dog. Narrated by Johnny Morris.

results.title: Plants, pests and diseases: flea beetles - halticinae
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the various species of the beetle and treats in detail the life cycle of one type - the striped flea beetle. Illustrates mating in the spring, hatching of the eggs and feeding of larvae on plant roots; burrowing of the larva into the soil for pupation. Time-lapse cinematography is used to record the whole of the ten-day life cycle of the beetle. Destruction to plant life by adult insects is also illustrated.
results.title_for_label: Plants, pests and diseases: flea beetles - halticinae
results.creator_credit_for_label: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit

results.title: Plants that live in water
results.brief_description: From a pond to the sea, we investigate the structure of plants suited for life in the water. Careful distinction is made between two major plant groups. Examples of the simplest group, the algae, range from microscopic “pond scum” to giant kelps. Examples of plants with true leaves, stems and roots range from eloda to water hyacinth, water lily and lotus.

results.title: Plants that grow from leaves, stems and roots. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: This film contains sophisticated vocabulary with limited explanations. It shows plant growth covering bulbs, corns, tubers, etc. and concentrates on asexual reproduction as required by orchardists and horticulturalist. The contents are comprehensive and the time-lapse photography very good. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
